reviewText:
I still remember when I got the game, it was an accident...
My friend gave me a demo cd with a bunch of games on it and cossacks: back to war was one of em.
I kept play that one demo mission again and again...
I think STILL this is the best strategy game of all time, it amazes me how you can control thousands, big cities and navy fleets.
And it takes hundreds of hours to finish the game because there is so much missions in it and of course an editor too.
And this strategy game is unique because the game mechanics are so different than most of the other strategy games, you dont have to rush for resources, there is always a few mine places around you where you can get the resources from.
But it takes a long time to upgrade yourself and meanwhile you have to defend yourself too and thats why almost all of the missions takes 2-3 hours to finish, so this makes you feel like you are in a real hardcore war I think.
I had so much epic battles in this game

reviewText:
It was one of my first computer games and it's still one of my favorites!

-Amazing battles
-Many possible strategies : mortars to attack from a huge distance, cavalry to attack the rearguard or to quickly pillage mines, officers and drums to make troop formations (up to 196 soldiers with one officer)...
-Enormous battlegrounds filled with soldiers (up to 10 000 if I remember correctly)!
-A lot of available countries with different architectures and troops
-Possibility to capture citizens, artillery and buildings with only some simple soldiers (there are priests too but they can heal a bit)
-Interesting use of ressources (to be able to fire you need coal, to keep mercenaries on your side you need gold etc.) so if your coal mines get captured for example you can no longer fire anything! (of course you can buy coal on the market but the prices can vary a lot depending on your behavior)
-Pretty good soundtracks

It's often really cheap on sales so if you enjoy RTS games, grab it!

reviewText:
I've been playing Cossacks for 13 years and I can say that it's the best rts I've played.
Pros:
-Extensive economy
-Massive battles (at land and sea)
-Various strategies for winning, depending on circumstances,terrain and your nation's and opponents' features.
-Buildings are exact replicas of real ones all over Europe
-100 single missions
-9 campaigns
-Taking advantage of the terrain is my favourite aspect of this game.You can place artillery on high ground,musketeers on either side of a passage for ambush,build walls and towers on strategic positions, block bridges  etc.

Cons:
-Apart from a couple of minor bugs,none whatsoever.

I tried playing age of empires and empire earth,after having played cossacks for a time,and I just couldn't! They are, definitely,inferior games.

reviewText:
Incredibly good game. Been playing this for over 10 years with a friend and we're still impressed by it.

-The game has an excellent balance between different unit types.
-The nations are varied enough to keep it enjoyable for a long time. Some nations may be very slightly over powered though e.g. Poland and Ukraine
-Seemingly endless single missions and enjoyable campaign.
-Art style is good and will likely age very well over time.
-Good resource ideas.
-Good upgrade trees

-One downsides is poor AI, which uses the same tactics constantly, just with increasingly larger numbers of units.
-The blue and black team colors are difficult to see on the map sometimes, while the white color is easily confused with the unit selected color on the map.
-The mine locator upgrade obsures your mines on the map making them difficult to locate ironically.
-No options for reforging alliances after the game has started.
-Multiplayer over internet is difficult to set up initially

reviewText:
One of the best strategy games out there. Spend hundreds of hours playing this game back when it just came out (ahh... nostalgia). Some campaign missions are insanely hard, even on normal difficulty, unlike most 'modern' strategy games in which you can usually beat the entire campaign without real effort (which is rather boring, I like having hard missions!). You can actually have huge scale battles on land or on sea in this game with thousands of units. Every battle will be unique because of all the different nations you can choose to play.

TL;DR
I only have one piece of advice: stop reading reviews. This game costs just 5 euros (or even less when its on sale). Buy it. Now.

reviewText:
Here's my review for Cossacks, I'll go for the negatives first which are few.
- I've recently got into the game just a while back, I can understand why it eventually became overshadowed by other RTS strategies like Age of Empire (AoE). It is not exactly a classic that can meet to todays options.
- There is a huge learning curve, the tutorials are extremely hard to understand working on a story line based script that throws you essentially into a game with some start up bonuses (note I did the one trying to understand military movements and got wrecked in the tutorial in minutes).
- Controls are more rugged than modern strategies understandably and this can be a deterrent if you're not willing to put the time into play it.
- Unlike franchises like Civilization and other games with Strategic Alliance emphasis there is no Diplomacy, its either 2v2s, 3v3s 4v4s or FFA. Don't expect the AI to give out on you if you make a blunder or get annihilated by them (don't expect if from strangers on Multi-player) they will continue to destroy you until you lose or rage *note, I did the first couple of games, which I normally don't do*.
- Understandably, Multiplayer is no where near as large as other strategy games, I haven't played multi enough to judge is characteristics of its gamers' virtues.

Now the positives of the game which to me outweigh its slight love obstacles.
- Simplistic design does not mean you have to over analysis, there is one goal, kill everyone else.
- Game runs on a simple quasi-rock/paper/scissors game mixed with a tacticians prowess and unit leadership.
- With friends you can build massive empires and role-play the ♥♥♥♥ out of this game, only with friends and Multiplayer.
- Remarkable graphics (for its time) that can arguably stand up to this day.
- Replaybility and saving in the midst of battles are nice, as well as restarting a game with the same map or different starting armies.
- You can choose between historic powers of the 1600s and 1700s, like France, Britian, Turkey, Bavaria, Prussia, Saxony, Russia, Netherlands, Venice, Spain, Portugal, Denmark, Sweden, Poland and others!
-Up to 8 players in a match with great challenging AI, even at Easy.
- Its a cheap affordable game which should work on any computer *note I'm running this on a Windows 8, not Win 8.1 with 4th Gen i3 and 4 GB of RAM*
-Its a game that if you are familiar with the Total War Series should remind you of an arcadey version of Empire Total War, *note without turn base, diplomacy or agents, and the fact that this game is more 2d than Empire*.

I would say this is a must buy if you have the patience, heart and  tolerance to get be humbled by the good AI system or a Human player, its cheap and fun. Also I haven't tried any of the 'DLC' or Expansion Packs as they were known back then. I hope this helps you make your decision ultimately, I wish you best of luck on the battlefield if you get the game.

reviewText:
A timeless classic. It has all the usual features that RTS games of that time tended to have.. and more!

Here are some features that make this game especially awesome and which many contemporaries lack (e.g. AoE, Warcraft, C&C):

- automatic infinite production loops of units (so you don't click yourself to death trying to constantly refill the ranks of your troops)
- armies CAN get huge (easily over 1,000+ per player) and WILL get huge (due to the ease of producing lots of units)
- more realism: your swordfighters won't be able to hit a building with melee weapons magically setting it on fire and eventually destroying it, instead, most buildings can be captured, and buildings can be destroyed only using artillery or certain specific unit types (standard settings)
- very flexible game speed (single player only): you can play it really slow to follow every single move your units make, useful when building up a base, or insanely fast to the point where you'll have trouble keeping up with understanding whats going on during a battle

reviewText:
Classic RTS.

Consists of fast or slow paced civilization building with unique nations, you can control thousands of units at any moment, and the game features a realistic--and equally unforgiving--resource/economy system not seen in many RTSs.

During its prime the game looked quite beautiful, and while I can't confirm you can play multiplayer with your friends, the single-player campaign is quite challenging and you will face challenging overwhelming forces more often than not.

It's quite cheap on Steam, and you will find a lot of value for your dollar.

Edited - 6/10/15

reviewText:
Many of you may be asking whether this is a game worth picking up. Some of you may be turned off by the graphics but believe me, this is one heck of a fun game to play. I'm a person who will try any game no matter how old the graphics as long as its is addicting and fun to play.

Actually, this one of my favorite RTS Games of all time. With tons of nations to choose from each with their own distinct characteristics, it will definitely keep you playing for hours end on end fielding gigantic armies and swift yet powerful navies to throw at your enemies.

I recently bought this game here in Steam just to get a secure copy of the game because mu old CD is now broke. I've probably sunk hundreds or perhaps more than a thousand hours into this game since I started playing it 8 years ago and I still enjoy it today! If you don't mind the look of the graphics and want a great strategy game to sink your teeth into, you should definitely try Cossacks: Back to War (^_^)

reviewText:
Couldn't tell you whether to get this or any of the other from the original Cossack(tm) series. Most of them say this, and I own them all on GOG.com.

At any rate, I can't recommend this enough! If you're a history buff like me, and/or fan of strategy games then you're bound to like this. There are not many, and especially well made, pike and shot games out there. Believe me, this is one of the few fantastic ones. And for the price it's hard to beat. There are some 20 nations to choose from, each unique with advantages and disadvantages, and each offer different challenges and opportunities.

Just how a strategy game should play.
Just buy it, I doubt you'll regret it!

reviewText: Very good classic RTS

One of those games where I got the most fun.
Start with a couple peasants around 17th century - build houses,buildings,town halls, barracks, maintain your resources and generate a whole city! Create an army to destroy the enemy city, choose your own nation in the lobby or also choose which players are allied or enemy (without internet, it's player vs bots and player can choose to ally with anyone).

I mean, what can not be more fun than create a city, destroy enemy's city, and build even more city on the dust of the destroyed enemy city? You can build out to a world leader! but then you get a victory message, unless some random superheroe comes out of nowhere and kicks your whole nation.

reviewText:
Cossacks Back to War is a very old RTS that focuses on building huge armies of 10.000+ units per player with tactical 18th century combat using variety of canons,upgrades and naval warfare .

You can use generals to build formations that give melee bonuses, use cavalry for flanks (which is actually very effective ) and canons for long range siege .In its own right this is one of the best game in the genre .

Since all units and buildings are made in sprites rather than 3d models this game still looks pretty good .

Go to options and reduce game speed when you playing single player ;)

reviewText:
This one's a bit different from cossacks 2.  It is a lot more like Age of the Empires in the sense of gameplay.

It takes place in the Napoleonic Wars.

I believe Age of the Empires 3 ripped off this game, and put a lower unit cap.

My attachement to the game is the scope.  You control squads of 196 men (At least I do).  That is a lot for a game like age of the empires.  A comparable game series would be Stronghold.  I checked, and the global unit cap is none.  WOW.  So yeah, feel free to use your math to figure out how many is too many and crashes the computer.

I also must mention the imperium mod here.  I adds the 19th century, and balances a few things.  Of note is that there is diplomacy, and other things.

Also, the upgrade system is pretty extensive.  You will NEVER research everything.  Well, unless you play defensive the whole game, and stall your opponent until that point.  I do that in Cossacks 2 to my friend.  :P

Oh yeah, I've played Age of the Empires 3, and this game is EASILY superior.

reviewText:
Product received for free

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs
3 tablespoons sugar
3 tablespoons melted butter
40 ounces softened cream cheese
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons flour
1 tablespoon vanilla
1 cup sour cream
4 eggs

Directions:
For The base:.
If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.
Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.
Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.
For the batter:.
Make sure everything is at room temperature.
Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.
Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.
Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.
Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.
Release the sides of the springform.
Eat.

reviewText: Was one of the best RTS for me. I like the fact that you can make (almost) unlimited units if you can pay for housing. ALs the unlimited supply of every resource is somewhat unique in this genre. The game just feels right and the computer gives you a tough challenge until you master the game. The AI can't deal with peace time though.\n\nI would only recommend this game for single player, as multiplayer can be a pain in the butt. I've had problems even connecting for LAN games with my friends and if you lose connection for more than 10 seconds during a game, you are defeated and there's nothing you can do about it.

Oh this game takes me back... It was the late 90's. Gaming hadn't quite devloped into the modern behemoth that it is today and adventuresome games were as common as dragons in Skyrim - not everywhere, but you knew for certain they did exist.

Cossacks is a base-building, tech-researching RTS that has a world of charm despite being rough around the edges. Set bewteen the 16th and 18th centuries in Europe, Cossacks: European Wars and Cossacks: Back to War (the standalone expansion) cover roughly twenty nations from Poland to Portugal, from Algeria to Ukraine - and just about everything inbetween.

Battles are fought with ranged and melee infantry and cavalry, as well as land-based artillery and naval units. The number of units the game can display on screen at any one time is in the thousands, as I recall. Enough so that an army can look like a literal blood-stain seeping across the map.

Resources aren't just for purchasing units, but are also required for upkeep. What this means is: run out of coal and you run out of gunpowder. Run out of gold and your units can mutiny. Run out of gold after you've built a ship-of-the-line and you'll have a mutinous unit on the order of a Renaissance Death Star" gone rogue.

While this might sound like it requires a great deal of micromanagement
date: it's actually fairly easy to keep track of - just monitor your resource counters at the top of the screen. If one starts to drop
recommended: start some research or throw some more peasants at it. If your food drops below zero
hoursPlayed: your units will begin to starve.\n\nSome other great concepts found in the Cossacks series: Peacetime in multiplayer. Essentially
voteText: you can agree to a set amount of Peacetime - a period where you cannot make aggressive moves. Well
votesHelpful: but your units will die when they cross the peacetime borders. This allows for the construction of intricate defenses and massed strategic-level armies.\n\nAnother favorite feature of mine and often copied by other games is the right-click-drag to change facing. I can't swear that Cossacks is the first series to use this feature
votesTotal: but it definitely was the first one that I'd played.\n\nThe game's default speed is incredibly fast on modern computers
votesFunny: but it can be slowed down to suit your needs - or sped up if you feel you've really just had way too much caffeine today.\n\nAll in all a stellar example of base-building RTS. Limited scope and limited marketing kept the game from the rightful place it deserves among the genre
commentsCount: but the game is far more than worth it.\n\nDownsides? Don't expect much in the way of tutorial. You'll also need to really read through the Academy (the main research structure) as well as the Blacksmith and other structures to find all the tech and research upgrades. If you don't mind all of that
column16: you'll find a true diamond in the rough."

reviewText:
Used to have Cossacks Back to War on disk, gave up after it became really complicated to make it run on Windows 8. This steam edition worked flawlessly for me right from the start, allowing me to enjoy great single player action in this classic game.

Multiplayer unfortunately is the part that never worked properly for me, despite spending hours combing through all the advice and recommendations. Only a wired connection allowed me to play with friends at home, and even then it didn't work every time we tried. Online play seems even less stable for me, although other people seem to have got it to work no problem.

6/10 - Great single player experience from a great classic game. Multiplayer is a little unstable unfortunately - some people have got it to work without too many problems, others like me are still trying after weeks.

This game is a must have for anyone who loves the Age of Empires series and just great RTS in general. This game doesn't use any fancy graphics engine but it does feature some great artistic presentation that paints a colorful picture. First of all the ability to chose from a giant variety of nations is amazing. Every nation has its strengths and weaknesses. Ex. Chinese start out with more peasants and have a better economy regulation, while Ukraine excels at firearms and cavalry, but lacks any cold steel infantry. So playing a different nation every time will give you a totally different feel. Sound effects are top notch in this game, ranging from atmospheric distant and close cannon fire, to nature sounds, to soldiers dying on a battlefield. There are a ton of factors that make this game superb so I won't bother mentioning them all. One last and important aspect that I will mention is the ability to literally control THOUSANDS of units at once. Imagine Age of Empires roids. That quality definitely adds an epic feel to the battles.\nI probably put over a 1,000 hours into this game back in the days, that how much replayability it has. I was feeling nostalgic lately so decided to pick it up on Steam and give it a try once more.

Used to play this years ago. Thought it was great at the time. Last year I bought Age of Empires on Steam to get back into old style RTS but found it uninteresting. Recently I noticed Cossacks was in the Store and bought it. Worked first time though the second time I tried to play it I had to set the game mode in Windows as per the help instructions on Steam. Been perfect since then.\n\nIt's just as good as ever. Just had a massive war with over 40,000 casualties. Horrific scenes, but that's the game of Cossacks. I was playing a random map against AI on hard and they still did some silly things and missed obvious opportunities (like the enemy ships did not attack my buildings) so the AI is not perfect but the game play is still fun and challenging and does not look too dates, apart from perhaps the menu screens.
